case_vignette: A 26-year-old man presents to the behavioral health clinic for assistance overcoming his fear of public speaking. He has always hated public speaking. Two weeks ago, he was supposed to present a research project at school but had to leave the podium before the presentation. He recalled that his heart was racing, his palms were sweating, and that he could not breathe. These symptoms resolved on their own after several minutes, but he felt too embarrassed to return to college the next day. This had also happened in high school where, before a presentation, he started sweating and felt palpitations and nausea that also resolved on their own. He is scheduled for another presentation next month and is terrified. He states that this only happens in front of large groups and that he has no problems communicating at small gatherings. Other than his fear of public speaking, he has a normal social life and many friends. He enjoys his classes and a part-time job.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I get really nervous, my heart starts beating fast, my hands sweat a lot, and sometimes I feel like I can't breathe when I have to speak in front of many people.
Have you had these symptoms before?
Yes, I've had these symptoms before, like in high school during a presentation when I started sweating, felt my heart pounding, and felt sick to my stomach.
Have you ever been diagnosed with anxiety or panic disorder?
No, I have not been diagnosed with anxiety or panic disorder.
Have you ever been prescribed medication for anxiety or panic disorder?
No, I have never been prescribed medication for anxiety or panic disorder.
Have you ever had any family members with anxiety or panic disorder?
I don't know of any family members with anxiety or panic disorder.
Have you ever had any traumatic events in your life?
No, I haven't had any traumatic events in my life.
Have you ever had any stressful events in your life?
No specific stressful events are mentioned in my history, just the general fear of public speaking.
Have you ever had any other symptoms related to anxiety or panic disorder?
Other than the symptoms when speaking in front of large groups, I haven't mentioned any other anxiety or panic disorder symptoms.
Final Diagnosis: Social Anxiety Disorder.

trial_0.summarized_conversation: The client reports feeling very nervous, with symptoms such as a fast-beating heart, excessive sweating, and difficulty breathing when speaking in front of a large audience. These symptoms have been experienced before, particularly during a presentation in high school. The client has not been diagnosed with anxiety or panic disorder, nor have they been prescribed any medication for these conditions. They deny any family history of anxiety or panic disorder and do not report any traumatic events in their life. Other than the symptoms experienced during public speaking, the client does not exhibit any other anxiety or panic disorder symptoms.
trial_0.vignette_frq: The most likely diagnosis is social anxiety disorder.
trial_0.multiturn_mcq: Final Diagnosis: Panic disorder with agoraphobia.
trial_0.summarized_frq: The most likely diagnosis is social anxiety disorder.
